7981B54E0A2444CAAF20C564B0071A8E.description: Reflect on personal commitment to working safely at all times.

F5991228A6224C3C9BBCE4D7DFFE31A3.description: Develop a list of rules for workplace safety that apply to all regardless of the workplace; sample rules include: Safety in the workplace is a personal and shared responsibility. Dress appropriately and wear personal protective equipment when required. Know emergency evacuation plans and procedures. Keep work areas neat and tidy. Know and follow workplace rules and procedures for working safety. Know personal or individual risks in the workplace and strategies to manage them. Know the procedure for reporting workplace accidents or safety incidents.

687D7C50CD2E4F52B241D80C2D7E9E2A.description: Analyze a variety of given scenarios pertaining to the tourism sector to identify potential hazards and safety risks and recommend strategies for preventing workplace injuries.

02373BF9BF034FA59659E224CF1CE6D0.description: Research statistics related to injuries that are common in each of the five industries (i.e., food and beverage, accommodation, recreation and entertainment, transportation, and travel services) in Saskatchewan and Canada.

F7D58990D1D8468381ECC232DAFB24AA.description: Develop strategies to mitigate risks identified for each of the five industries.

0C8FF884CA6D463AA7F9F735A908C3FB.description: Discuss risk mitigation and its purpose.

8153CC88CBD146D7966B4653BA2D7307.description: Identify potential safety hazards and risks in each of the five tourism industries. Examples may include: exposure to cleaning products and other chemicals; musculoskeletal injuries from standing for long hours; slips, trips or falls; and burns from dishes, meals or drinks that are hot (food and beverage); ergonomic hazards (e.g., from bending, pushing carts and making beds); slips, trips and falls; respiratory, dermal and carcinogenic hazards from chemicals in cleaning products (accommodation); lifting and handling heavy loads; working at heights; extreme temperatures; exposure to chemicals in liquids such as paints, solvents, cleaners and bleach; and working alone (recreation and entertainment); distracted driving; failure to safety check vehicles; and driver fatigue (transportation); and, working alone in the office; excessive computer use; improper ergonomics (travel services)

948550A5F69845A686FE96BC72A9C915.description: Research employer, supervisor and employee responsibilities pertaining to occupational health and safety standards in the workplace as required by Saskatchewan law.

5061CA3CCFFB4AC482A2E8C033C95255.description: Discuss the importance to self and others (e.g., customers, colleagues, employer, family and friends) of working safely at all times.

4C8985FDCB5E48478083277931FC45A3.description: Examine strategies for ensuring safety in the tourism workplace.

025B936CE17945768977CCF607683D20.description: Create and present a travel promotion package for a community or area within Saskatchewan including information that references: all five industries (i.e., food and beverage, accommodation, recreation and entertainment, transportation, and travel services); impacts on social, environmental, cultural and economic sustainability; considerations for personal safety; and other pertinent information (e.g., availability of basic items, requirements for travel documentation and medical requirements.)

1597C0124FC04585AFCBDDA81B5A5844.description: Identify the historical and cultural contributions of other groups such as the French, Doukhobors and Ukrainians to the area.

96C13FC6153544F1BB6761FB53F5F1F1.description: Examine the historical and cultural contributions of Métis, First Nations, and Inuit peoples to the area.

376C60B664C24887A36A3D03347D52E6.description: Research answers to questions related to the geography of the community or area, such as: location - Where is it (e.g., absolute location, referencing latitude and longitude and relative location, referencing other locations)? Why is it there?, place – What is it like there, considering both physical and human characteristics?, human/environment interaction – What is the relationship between humans and the environment? How has the landscape been shaped by humans?, movement – What examples of movement of people, goods or ideas are present? Has immigration impacted the area? What are the modes of transportation and transportation routes? region – In what region is it located, and how is it similar or dissimilar to other regions?

D67C99637B8348D6972A495AF4249C86.description: Create a travel promotion package for a destination within Saskatchewan.

60CCE67C6C0D42379D37B990D6D1867C.description: Create and present a marketing campaign which uses the 5 Ps (i.e., product, place, price, promotion, partnership and packaging) and C (convenience) of the tourism marketing mix.

3A2F446D21034168B8BBF7E99EC0EE70.description: Analyze the pros and cons of various opportunities to determine the best option(s) for a class or group project.

E14AF5B588D4478E962829E6F7287551.description: Identify new or existing tourism opportunities in one or more of the five industries (i.e., food and beverage, accommodation, recreation and entertainment, transportation, and travel services) within the community.

482D883A0F8F46FA8206B8A23CADA1B4.description: Create a marketing campaign for a tourism opportunity within the school or local community.

18BCA96AEEED4DCCBF649E868AB307E4.description: Research travel etiquette appropriate for a variety of global destinations.

462334141020490AAA1DA39C8346F6E2.description: Reflect on travel etiquette for a variety of scenarios such as flying on an airplane, camping in a campground, renting a car and dining in a family restaurant or formal dining establishment.

E454B55EFC3E4DDCB4C98EDA2F8FFE85.description: Create pre-travel checklists for a variety of travel scenarios (e.g., camping in a provincial park for the weekend, flying to Toronto to take in a musical production or concert or driving to Winnipeg to attend a Winnipeg Jets home game).

28FB8847F5CE43B2BF31FF3F2129D149.description: Identify potential hazards and risks associated with travelling to a variety of destinations and propose strategies for mitigating them.

7668883F0ED8430D8D7480418DC21D59.description: Brainstorm a list of details and items (e.g., travel documentation such as visas or passports, currency exchange, credit/debit cards, travel insurance, luggage/baggage and the types/sizes, international driver’s license, vaccinations, medications, and clothing and toiletries) that travellers should consider prior to travelling.

77695256FCD34D468DCA3ED12537D293.description: Discuss the advantages (e.g., alleviating stress and last-minute decisions) of preparing a pre-travel checklist.

9667418886DC424D80A88B62C2684FCB.description: Reflect on factors that influence an individual’s travel preferences such as: age; stage of life; purpose of travel (e.g., leisure, business and family); personal interests and interests of travel companions; time of year; and, budget/finances.

9F4BA8C9345B4B48BD19D380F5B397CC.description: Discuss the importance of pre-planning before travelling.

699D46DD3D9740299E92761FEA1C3D90.description: Investigate elements that support successful travel planning as a tourist.

6828CA1EECB347019A70CCD8A251D57E.description: Differentiate between destination marketing organizations (e.g., Tourism Regina and Tourism Saskatoon) and provincial marketing organizations (e.g., Tourism Saskatchewan) and the roles they play in the tourism sector.

9C59D58BCE4847E0A4D5DC8E0489A945.description: Identify the 5 Ps and C of the tourism marketing mix applied to various local and provincial examples (e.g., a local summer fair, sports tournament, cultural event or trade show; Tunnels of Moose Jaw; Regina Folk Festival; Canadian Western Agribition; or a Saskatchewan Roughrider home game).

58B577A25AE84FE3B861A0B7A76D8665.description: Examine the value of conducting market research (e.g., helps determine the target audience and viability of product/idea/experience and helps one identify competitors) when considering the tourism marketing mix.

B93730023A5E405FB108165CD26572EF.description: Discuss the importance of each element of the tourism marketing mix known as the 5 Ps and C (i.e., product, place, price, promotion, partnership and packaging, and convenience).

89CF4E41D5034B4BA711B5764B16A4E5.description: Describe potential benefits (e.g., economic, social and cultural) of marketing for the tourism sector.

E4211E17950E4B03B8A66D79DAD75B1B.description: Define marketing and describe its purpose.

B4E4CA2001BB49E1A91D9A8160671D03.description: Analyze the purpose and benefits of tourism marketing.

8FFDE91F996943DD98EF3CFCB0E42955.description: Role-play and analyze situations that demonstrate positive and negative customer experiences using: verbal, non-verbal (e.g., body language) and written communication; active listening skills; conversation starters; and/or, questioning skills.

B63CDF5A33104F7DBE0DFE8D6C53E8A1.description: Reflect on positive and negative customer experiences personally observed or encountered.

29C98C44E0344C21BD8863C8BA9BE93F.description: Suggest ways to effectively deal with a situation when denial of customer service is warranted.

E2BFE38CAF384D2D94A614B5F7BCECC0.description: Research acceptable reasons (e.g., violent or threatening behaviour, intoxication and theft) for refusing service to a customer.

EC5C8641E16E477FADA0CC5268285D0D.description: Analyze customer rights to service and protection from discrimination as provided by the Human Rights Act of Canada and the Saskatchewan Human Rights Code.

D1618A53BF3E46F490D56A264DAD1A89.description: Strategize approaches to accommodate and effectively serve customers from diverse backgrounds (e.g., cultural, social and demographic) and with diverse needs (e.g., accessibility, communication and mobility).

7C6B58520A0846D78522AC036CFF872E.description: Describe ways to provide a good first impression when serving a customer in a tourism job.

71F4E96704CE4ABC94E2B3F592A3D756.description: Discuss the importance of a first impression and its impact on the visitor experience.

921E6C0BA29C4FB597180B6BCEE06299.description: Identify fundamental principles (e.g., respect, reliability, accountability, caring and responsiveness) of good customer service.

803690966E2C4B23BB15C462B6B5EE77.description: Investigate the impact of customer service on the visitor experience.

33FE4D49B95C43ADBE5EC4BDC8125D75.description: Reflect on and commit to undertaking personal actions that demonstrate professionalism and being a good ambassador for one’s school and/or community.

6E83BDE92D12408BB2CF26441E74E932.description: Discuss what it means to be a good ambassador for a community.

D3562E3CFF7F4B5AA7635D4204FDD8E9.description: Reflect on the potential impact of personal beliefs and unconscious bias on relationships and interactions with clients and co-workers in the workplace.

C5D8BCB76FB54B9681B224C32F266CB7.description: Assess the importance of acknowledging and respecting customer diversity.

DC381816EA1C46D29EA8093D7181E5D9.description: Examine the contributions of employees and volunteers and how their actions and attitudes can positively or negatively shape the identity of a business, community, province and country.

24468ECE81654EAEAE5F8B4DE05542A9.description: Discuss: the importance of professional appearance, good personal hygiene and conduct for a career in tourism; professional etiquette in using a variety of communication tools such as email, telephone, social media and smart phone applications both on- and off-the-job while employed in the tourism industry; and, common ethical standards (e.g., confidentiality and privacy) related to customer service in the tourism industry.

21628A0D5C844ACEAED006B0BE0F5DC3.description: Describe personal qualities and behaviours (e.g., demonstrating a positive attitude; showing responsibility; being adaptable; showing respect for self and others; demonstrating communication skills; and being an ambassador for one’s school, community and province) that demonstrate professionalism as it relates to working in the tourism industry.

97283D8DCFD74183B410D9B11162C943.description: Examine the importance of professionalism for workers in the tourism sector.

A66968C183CB4C4990B419C6B94FE5F1.description: Discuss the impact (e.g., economic and other) of unforeseen events such as a global pandemic, natural disaster (e.g., earthquake or tornado) or man- made catastrophe (e.g., 9/11) on the travel services industry.

73C79100EB8A43319EF17E7D45AD8B33.description: Develop an information package that addresses typical visitors’ inquiries about the local and surrounding area and/or province.

610698E6235F4955989F7BAFD4E00CD3.description: Suggest reasons why customers might access: travel agents; tourism call centres; visitor information centers; and, tour operators.

5E0D3C76875B43D3BF1A835CA2AA38BE.description: Identify services (e.g., online, pamphlets and guidebooks) commonly available from travel services.

D0946ED0D9DD43119A311EF3EAD11245.description: Describe the interrelatedness of the travel services industry and other tourism industries (i.e. food and beverage, accommodation, recreation and entertainment and transportation).

A58DA3C043A24E4199A56C61533CDCD2.description: Identify examples of the travel services industry within the local community and/or province.

989F3F94AA8648E8909EC538E230FAD4.description: List examples of the types of businesses and services (e.g., travel agents, tourism call centers, visitor information centres and tour operators) provided by the travel services industry.

83506471B4CE4B1DBF471CA95C5BA1D5.description: Explore the travel services industry and its interrelatedness to other industries within the tourism sector.

35973223D53D4C97AB71F5475138F15C.description: Discuss the impact (e.g., economic and other) of unforeseen events such as a global pandemic, natural disaster (e.g., earthquake or tornado) or man- made catastrophe (e.g., 9/11) on the transportation industry.

7648802A481E4ACF95C96F05DB5C645C.description: Explore trends (e.g., sharing economy) that have impacted or may impact the transportation industry.

B63DD26C0FFB412398E24ABDDD027A11.description: Analyze the challenges associated with urban and rural transport systems in Saskatchewan.

92B86F4BC2BD457AA6259F66DDBA064B.description: Discuss factors (e.g., price, availability, personal preference, availability, accessibility, distance and duration of trip) that determine a traveller’s choice for a mode of transportation.

7A901AAA286E43F6B6774652DC69E199.description: Examine the interrelatedness among the transportation industry and other tourism industries.

B2EFBA7A224C4A4CB0CEC954F8431CB3.description: Identify modes of transportation available within the community and surrounding area and/or province.

74645319989F4BF8AF431C6E5E1FE040.description: List modes of transportation (e.g., airplanes, taxis, personal vehicles, trains, limousines and ride sharing) typically found within the transportation industry.

57D2C7B0225B466FA5B479DAB72CC4B5.description: Explore the transportation industry and its interrelatedness to other industries within the tourism sector.

BAB9C4F7A4254B0082BEA71E6A9C7A3C.description: Discuss the impact (e.g., economic and human) of unforeseen events such as a global pandemic, natural disaster (e.g., earthquake or tornado) or man- made catastrophe (e.g., 9/11) on the recreation and entertainment industry.

E1B2088F2D70480896550B426396FC28.description: Research trends (e.g., growing popularity of artificial intelligence, influence of virtual and augmented reality, decreased leisure time and increased or decreased disposable income) that may impact the recreation and entertainment industry.

DDE91F864B364EE2956CA36DCFBED569.description: Summarize potential economic spinoffs to a community resulting from local recreation and entertainment activities, events or venues.

7286731AD75D4C21BD7C902EA6FBF185.description: Explain factors (e.g., cost, location, length and accessibility) that influence an individual’s choice to participate in recreation and entertainment opportunities.

0333CC8AAA0C4B9B836C15E398092A98.description: Examine the interrelatedness among the recreation and entertainment industry and other tourism industries.

711BA768FDF54BAC92878CA3CDF3B6AF.description: Identify examples of the recreation and entertainment industry within the local community and/or province.

214556D37C724BEB86A8BED3D662A0F5.description: List examples of the types of opportunities (e.g., attractions, museums, art galleries, sporting events, adventure tourism, nature-based tourism, outdoor/indoor recreation, festivals, cultural events, sporting events and dramatic/musical performances) within the recreation and entertainment industry.

59E9DD82EB184F08B2EBE14D548F26AD.description: Explore the recreation and entertainment industry and its interrelatedness to other industries within the tourism sector.

76CA93D9CF6143829F820B38ED1CA8BC.description: Discuss the impact (e.g., economic and other) of unforeseen events such as a global pandemic, natural disaster (e.g., earthquake or tornado) or man- made catastrophe (e.g., 9/11) on the accommodation industry.

7BE4632320814E1ABF4682D8DACEA43E.description: Identify trends (e.g., sharing economy and self-service options) that may impact the accommodation industry.

2E8CF8D0D2774C5389E02A70267BC46C.description: Examine factors (e.g., ratings, purpose of travel, previous experiences— both positive and negative, price, location, accessibility and amenities) that influence an individual’s choice for accommodation.

F2E4D9FD3D654557A320C17276E15FAF.description: Explain the interrelatedness among the accommodation and other tourism industries.

3EACBE1115B341199B40C058B005BA28.description: Classify examples of accommodation within the community and surrounding area and/or province according to the accommodation types.

2A87179EEA074DE384692E376EAE16D0.description: Describe common types of accommodation (e.g., hotel, motel, cabin, bed and breakfast, guest ranch, hostel and camp/campground).

417CEB6DEA874F8F8D79396AF8B1C5A7.description: Explore the accommodation industry and its interrelatedness to other industries within the tourism sector.

44275A8CA6C64A6B9BF6E37E8AAE4AEE.description: Explain the potential impact (e.g., economic and human) of unforeseen events such as a global pandemic, natural disaster (e.g., earthquake or tornado) or man-made catastrophe (e.g., 9/11) on the food and beverage industry.

1E3DA86AF3A34E33AB0C4A6961152E06.description: Identify trends (e.g., plant-based meat alternatives, gluten-free diet and 100-mile diet) within the food and beverage industry.

D8F6146736D44F01B53391526331D082.description: Discuss the interrelatedness among the food and beverage and other tourism industries (e.g., food and beverage as well as accommodation, transportation and/or travel services may be accessed by visitors attending an event).

4130456642DB42C9A5FE287CC2B6AC24.description: Differentiate between commercial and non-commercial food service operations.

CEC6C8A831FA40A09D4F24BB926FD829.description: Identify food artisans within the community and surrounding area or province.

7754CB908E434B3CA3EBA241B1B95BC0.description: Research characteristics of artisanal food (e.g., made locally using traditional methods and tools and local ingredients, and produced on a small-scale or in small batches).

5485932631D6467E90AECA3B6EAECCFC.description: Classify examples of food establishments within the community and surrounding area or province according to market segments (e.g., banquet service, buffet and smorgasbord, haute cuisine; family, speciality and chain restaurants; franchise; catering; entertainment; and institutional food service).

21C62F62E429442DB9DFEB2912BFEA02.description: Describe common types of food service (e.g., fast food service, fine dining, drive through service, pick up and delivery, catering, cafeteria, buffet style and family style) and provide examples of when each might be used.

511120A35B804605B31BC0C833BC0122.description: Explore the food and beverage industry and its interrelatedness to other industries within the tourism sector.

DABC7AF65EAD433AB28DD029A97636B4.description: Reflect on what it means to be a respectful and responsible tourist in Saskatchewan, including: acknowledging the traditional land and treaty territories situated within Saskatchewan; acknowledging the uniqueness of linguistic and cultural groups among First Nations, Métis and Inuit peoples; acknowledging and following traditional protocols; taking only, and all, personal belongings when leaving an area; recognizing and respecting local natural/traditional laws that are passed down from one generation to the next; and, being environmentally conscious.

AF2B602D6FB04BAE91C263221B011312.description: Investigate the connection and relationship of Métis, First Nations and Inuit peoples to the land in Saskatchewan and the resulting impact on tourism.

712931675D1745E8BF2A7BB6456D67AF.description: Summarize Saskatchewan’s competitive advantage in the tourism sector compared to other provinces and neighbouring American states.

76698E1E3DE34BA3A2895740A55D02BC.description: Discuss the concept of competitive advantage.

50C0FC5CE2354BCF941AC9751E52AB9F.description: Research how the tourism industry has capitalized, or could capitalize, on Saskatchewan’s natural capital (e.g., diversity, culture and natural landscape).

654D86D1CB4F497FB8E6C22CE6A2716B.description: Explain strategies used by tourism industries to increase customer count.

F2332896648341E5A282A384FBF675EC.description: List examples of urban and rural tourism experiences in Saskatchewan for each of the five industries.

2C39256449274224AD78A19949416A3D.description: Propose factors (e.g., pandemic, economic downturn or economic boom) that may contribute to periods of growth and decline in the tourism sector in Saskatchewan.

1C39979E6C73486FB70A8CBF6DF86491.description: Assess the attitudes and habits of Saskatchewanians pertaining to tourism in Saskatchewan.

496CDD7D0B954312B68A00376D566C63.description: Interpret statistics and facts related to tourism in Saskatchewan, such as: the number of people who work in tourism-related jobs; demographics of those who work in tourism; the number of visits to and within Saskatchewan; the region/province/country of origin of those who visit Saskatchewan; annual spending; most popular tourist attractions; and, top leisure activities.

CABDC0F0585F49D18E63747994B97CD2.description: Analyze regional differences in tourism in Saskatchewan.

BC0AB628348946DE8B5FF772A0A7124D.description: Discuss evolving expectations (e.g., experiencing nature and the outdoors, and enjoying local flavours and traditions) of travellers to the province and the resulting trends in tourism opportunities.

F6A14C779CF8458CB2EB155A780F5288.description: Compare the advantages and disadvantages of owning and operating a family-owned and operated business to owning and operating a franchised business.

F4E5ADEB9BEE4293988330BDB80E3701.description: Classify tourism businesses within the local community and surrounding area as family-owned and operated or as franchises.

69FB6AE77BD546369B386AD6BF7CC662.description: Research the evolution of tourism in Saskatchewan.

59A1AA5E844342CF92518760C7FFA143.description: Examine the role and impact of tourism in Saskatchewan.

F1B4E620A03E43A2AABDE4D386CFC6D9.description: Construct plans (i.e., for one and several days) for being a tourist within the local community and surrounding area, referencing all five industries in the tourism sector.

B7956ECCFC7F439A8A1AF4E96C0322E3.description: Discuss common characteristics (e.g., families with young children, hunters, sports enthusiasts, adults, artisans, Saskatchewan residents and residents from other provinces or countries) of tourists who typically visit the local community and surrounding area.

FEA8B87DDC5D4D768EBE0E420AF4EDD6.description: Brainstorm reasons why tourists visit the local community and surrounding area.

4E9B1255A1BF496BB0812046C6F923FC.description: Describe the local area, including ecosystems, landscape, climate, history, culture and people and their relationship to tourism.

B8E534089489474C946DE3110AB786C1.description: Research the connection and relationship of First Nations, Métis and Inuit peoples to the land in the local community and the surrounding area and the resulting impact on tourism.

64AB9BD757C3408FAAC5DBFBBFACB77F.description: Discuss the importance of tourism to the local community and surrounding area.

AAF941EBE166443BA3E877739B4BB5A6.description: Explore the role and impact of tourism on the local community and surrounding area.

A1D1BCC052EF4171B64F6DD6CB2D4651.description: Reflect on ways to be a responsible and respectful tourist and guest such as: researching local customs, languages and culture prior to visiting; being mindful of protected and sacred species and spaces; respecting the destination as though it is one’s home; conserving water (e.g., taking short showers and using towels for more than one day); supporting experiences and local ventures that have a positive social and environmental impact on the local community; using public transport when possible; purchasing authentic souvenirs and other goods from local artisans and enterprises; and, choosing food and beverage, accommodation, recreation and entertainment, transportation, and travel services that implement sustainable practices and policies.

7B10622B38BA49B5B188FCC35654A155.description: Research the origin, development and resulting impact of the Palau Pledge.

FE511E0444DA4BA598A6DB5FAC563EE4.description: Investigate potential positive and negative impacts of mass and alternative tourism on the environment, economy, culture and society.

93C6CCF8380743CF80D491B0C39ED160.description: Differentiate between mass and alternative tourism.

EF0BD7FA4C8A429EA58582DD0E2BED91.description: Describe the four components (i.e., environmental, economic, cultural and social) of sustainable tourism.

8ACC2277A7B242C8846044A52BFF5DB3.description: Discuss what sustainability is and why it is an important consideration for all tourism industries at the local, provincial, national and global level.

9AC61128EFCC4037A28427575E72C290.description: Analyze the importance of environmental, economic, cultural and social sustainability to the tourism sector.

5F182766A2E142298063F7976201592B.description: Create a plan, including anticipated expenditures, for a vacation to a destination of choice within Canada that supports one’s preferred type of tourism and references the five industries of tourism.

AB8F7303583C4DC0A103A557AEF02F85.description: Reflect on personal preference for a specific type of tourism and how that preference may evolve and change over time.

B2D98926C27944CA99965B3F6EBC1E16.description: Research the prevalence of, and provide examples for, each type of tourism found within the local community, Saskatchewan and/or Canada.

83A0C5F978C14AD9B235659A191563FB.description: Describe various types of tourism including: rural; cultural; health; adventure; culinary; urban/city; sports; education; ecotourism; business; and, global (i.e., export-ready).

F199F6D641C0438A92DB0E1233B5A96A.description: Investigate types of tourism found within the local community, Saskatchewan and/or Canada.

E8574836BC434B6D8916EDC07C4E4E4F.description: Identify examples of the five industries found within the community and the surrounding area.

8F4FCA4D89794327BD7CA710A9E34FC7.description: Investigate the five industries (i.e., food and beverage, accommodation, recreation and entertainment, transportation, and travel services) within the tourism sector.

B77ACC6E15964CCBB776D55AB1DF445E.description: Explain potential negative impacts (e.g., wear and tear, pollution, rising costs for local residents and overcrowding) of tourism on a community.

298E3E649D7F44AFA7E33ADA4CF731A3.description: Discuss reasons (e.g., economic and job opportunities) why tourism is important to an area and specifically the local area.

E0FC5779A3404E998D78F7FDBFB6881E.description: Analyze factors such as length of stay, purpose of visit, finances/budget, individual preferences, individual requirements (e.g., dietary restrictions and mobility issues) and time of year that help determine visitor needs for: where to stay (e.g., accommodation); where to eat (e.g., food and beverage); what to do (e.g., entertainment and recreation and visitor services); and, getting to and travelling within the destination (e.g., transportation).

9F042BC42B3D475290BDD4ECFC695759.description: Research what is meant by the term visitor economy.

3D3266ADD89047259B5837F154AFD707.description: Assess the relationship between culture and tourism.

99CF39B6BA6E47C4A5E609F1F5760083.description: Differentiate among outbound (i.e., Saskatchewan residents travelling out of province), inbound (i.e., out-of-province tourists travelling to and within the province) and domestic (i.e., Saskatchewan residents travelling within the province).

6CF562A4B76D4E16A7E4D1EC57924E7C.description: Discuss reasons (e.g., leisure, education, personal interests, disposable income and business) why people travel as tourists.

2E39EF4B4A9D4666835C905E83720EF0.description: Describe what tourism is and what it means to be a tourist.

C9592ABFA23A47A783FB2A4B04A1C020.description: Explore the cultural, economic and social impact of tourism.
